Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that language is selected for social contexts and that it helps to signal social roles and relationships
Topic: Understand that language is selected for social contexts and that it helps to signal social roles and relationships
Elaboration: Using language that signals the roles of chairperson and the different speaker positions in a debate
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •examples of the kinds of language expected in different situations, e.g. with friends, with the teacher, with a visitor to the classroom

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that language is selected for social contexts and that it helps to signal social roles and relationships
Topic: Understand that language is selected for social contexts and that it helps to signal social roles and relationships
Elaboration: Using language that signals the roles of chairperson and the different speaker positions in a debate
EALDElaboration: •practising in small groups or pairs

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that language is selected for social contexts and that it helps to signal social roles and relationships
Topic: Understand that language is selected for social contexts and that it helps to signal social roles and relationships
Elaboration: Identifying ways in which cultures differ in making and responding to common requests; for example, periods of silence, degrees of formality

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that language is selected for social contexts and that it helps to signal social roles and relationships
Topic: Understand that language is selected for social contexts and that it helps to signal social roles and relationships
Elaboration: Identifying some cultural protocols and communication processes of first nations australians

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how to move beyond making bare assertions by taking account of differing ideas or opinions and authoritative sources
Topic: Understand how to move beyond making bare assertions by taking account of differing ideas or opinions and authoritative sources
Elaboration: Recognising that a bare assertion (for example, “it's the best film this year.”) often needs to be tempered by: using the “impersonal it” to distance oneself (for example, “it could be said that it is the best film this year.”); recruiting anonymous support (for example, “it is generally agreed that it is the best film this year.”); indicating a general source of the opinion (for example, “most critics agree that it is the best film this year.”); specifying the source of the opinion (for example, “reviewers for the reel film stated that it is the best film this year.”) and reflecting on the effect of these different choices

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Describe how spoken, written and multimodal texts use language features and are typically organised into characteristic stages and phases, depending on purposes in texts
Topic: Describe how spoken, written and multimodal texts use language features and are typically organised into characteristic stages and phases, depending on purposes in texts
Elaboration: Becoming familiar with the typical stages and language features of types of texts such as narrative, procedure, arguments, explanation, discussion and informative texts, and how they can be composed in written, digital and multimedia forms to achieve their purpose

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Describe how spoken, written and multimodal texts use language features and are typically organised into characteristic stages and phases, depending on purposes in texts
Topic: Describe how spoken, written and multimodal texts use language features and are typically organised into characteristic stages and phases, depending on purposes in texts
Elaboration: Recognising that paragraphs vary in their function and how they are organised in a text and between different types of texts; for example, the differences between paragraphs in a narrative, an argument and a procedure

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Describe how spoken, written and multimodal texts use language features and are typically organised into characteristic stages and phases, depending on purposes in texts
Topic: Describe how spoken, written and multimodal texts use language features and are typically organised into characteristic stages and phases, depending on purposes in texts
Elaboration: Describing the stages and phases, and purposes of narratives, historical recounts, procedural recounts, causal explanations, discussions of alternative positions on an issue, information reports, reviews and types of poems

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how texts can be made cohesive by using the starting point of a sentence or paragraph to give prominence to the message and to guide the reader through the text
Topic: Understand how texts can be made cohesive by using the starting point of a sentence or paragraph to give prominence to the message and to guide the reader through the text
Elaboration: Observing how writers use the beginning of a sentence to signal to the reader how the text is developing; for example, “snakes are reptiles. they have scales and no legs. many snakes are poisonous. however, in australia they are protected.”

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how texts can be made cohesive by using the starting point of a sentence or paragraph to give prominence to the message and to guide the reader through the text
Topic: Understand how texts can be made cohesive by using the starting point of a sentence or paragraph to give prominence to the message and to guide the reader through the text
Elaboration: Recognising that a sequence of clauses may use different tenses but remain connected through a topic; for example, “snakes were a problem in australia. however, urban sprawl is ruining their habitats and they are now a protected species.”

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how texts can be made cohesive by using the starting point of a sentence or paragraph to give prominence to the message and to guide the reader through the text
Topic: Understand how texts can be made cohesive by using the starting point of a sentence or paragraph to give prominence to the message and to guide the reader through the text
Elaboration: Recognising that sentence openers signal what the sentence will be about, and the rest of the sentence typically elaborates on the sentence opener by providing new information

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that the structure of a complex sentence includes a main clause and at least one dependent clause, and understand how writers can use this structure for effect
Topic: Understand that the structure of a complex sentence includes a main clause and at least one dependent clause, and understand how writers can use this structure for effect
Elaboration: Knowing that complex sentences make connections between ideas to provide a reason; for example, “he jumped up because the bell rang.”; state a purpose; for example, “she raced home to confront her brother.”; express a condition; for example, “it will break if you push it.”; make a concession; for example, “she finished her work even though she was feeling tired.”; link 2 ideas in terms of various time relations; for example, “nero fiddled while rome burned.”
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •sentence models to modify by inserting their own content but retaining the structure

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how noun groups can be expanded in a variety of ways to provide a fuller description of a person, place, thing or idea
Topic: Understand how noun groups can be expanded in a variety of ways to provide a fuller description of a person, place, thing or idea
Elaboration: Learning how to expand a description by combining a related set of nouns and adjectives; for example, “two old brown cattle dogs”
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •interactive and oral activities to build students’ use of noun groups with visual support

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how noun groups can be expanded in a variety of ways to provide a fuller description of a person, place, thing or idea
Topic: Understand how noun groups can be expanded in a variety of ways to provide a fuller description of a person, place, thing or idea
Elaboration: Observing how descriptive details can be built up around a noun or an adjective, forming a group (for example, “this very smelly cleaning cloth in the sink” is a noun group and “as pretty as the flowers in may” is an adjective group)

Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas

Topic: Explain how the sequence of images in print, digital and film texts has an effect on meaning

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how vocabulary is used to express greater precision of meaning, including through the use of specialist and technical terms, and explore the history of words
Topic: Understand how vocabulary is used to express greater precision of meaning, including through the use of specialist and technical terms, and explore the history of words
Elaboration: Using precise words for naming; for example, instead of “mammal” or “whale”, using “humpback whale”
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •examining words being used differently in different contexts, e.g. ‘Stay in the shade’, ‘Shade one half of the circle’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how vocabulary is used to express greater precision of meaning, including through the use of specialist and technical terms, and explore the history of words
Topic: Understand how vocabulary is used to express greater precision of meaning, including through the use of specialist and technical terms, and explore the history of words
Elaboration: Using precise words for naming; for example, instead of “mammal” or “whale”, using “humpback whale”
EALDElaboration: •developing word clines to demonstrate the subtle differences in meaning, for example small, little, tiny, miniscule, microscopic

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how vocabulary is used to express greater precision of meaning, including through the use of specialist and technical terms, and explore the history of words
Topic: Understand how vocabulary is used to express greater precision of meaning, including through the use of specialist and technical terms, and explore the history of words
Elaboration: Exploring greek and latin roots in commonly used words; for example, the greek root word “tele” meaning distant in words such as “telephone” and “teleport”

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Use commas to indicate prepositional phrases, and apostrophes where there is multiple possession
Topic: Use commas to indicate prepositional phrases, and apostrophes where there is multiple possession
Elaboration: Learning that in standard australian english, regular plural nouns ending in “s” form the possessive by adding just the apostrophe; for example, “the students' classroom”

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Use commas to indicate prepositional phrases, and apostrophes where there is multiple possession
Topic: Use commas to indicate prepositional phrases, and apostrophes where there is multiple possession
Elaboration: Learning that in standard australian english for proper nouns, the regular possessive form is always possible but a variant form without the second “s” is sometimes found; for example, “james’s house” or “james’ house”

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Use commas to indicate prepositional phrases, and apostrophes where there is multiple possession
Topic: Use commas to indicate prepositional phrases, and apostrophes where there is multiple possession
Elaboration: Learning that when there is more than one owner, the apostrophe is usually used for the last owner in the list; for example, “the cat and kitten’s bowls”

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Use commas to indicate prepositional phrases, and apostrophes where there is multiple possession
Topic: Use commas to indicate prepositional phrases, and apostrophes where there is multiple possession
Elaboration: Using commas to signal a prepositional phrase; for example, “on saturday, before it rained we went to the beach.”

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify aspects of literary texts that represent details or information about historical, social and cultural contexts in literature by first nations australian, and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Topic: Identify aspects of literary texts that represent details or information about historical, social and cultural contexts in literature by first nations australian, and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Elaboration: Identifying aspects of literature; for example, images, symbols, dialogue and character descriptions, that can convey information about a context
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •inclusion of literary texts that reflect their cultural heritage, and opportunities to share ideas related to the details or information about historical, social and cultural contexts in these texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify aspects of literary texts that represent details or information about historical, social and cultural contexts in literature by first nations australian, and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Topic: Identify aspects of literary texts that represent details or information about historical, social and cultural contexts in literature by first nations australian, and wide-ranging australian and world authors

ContentDescription: Identify aspects of literary texts that represent details or information about historical, social and cultural contexts in literature by first nations australian, and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Topic: Identify aspects of literary texts that represent details or information about historical, social and cultural contexts in literature by first nations australian, and wide-ranging australian and world authors

ContentDescription: Identify aspects of literary texts that represent details or information about historical, social and cultural contexts in literature by first nations australian, and wide-ranging australian and world authors

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Present an opinion on a literary text using specific terms about literary devices, text structures and language features, and reflect on the viewpoints of others
Topic: Present an opinion on a literary text using specific terms about literary devices, text structures and language features, and reflect on the viewpoints of others
Elaboration: Posing and discussing questions, such as “should characters have behaved as they did?” and “how did the author support or challenge your belief about the characters?”, and beginning to make judgements about the dilemmas characters face
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •a range of options for responding to texts, including the use of visuals, the provision of a range of possible responses, and sentence prompts

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Present an opinion on a literary text using specific terms about literary devices, text structures and language features, and reflect on the viewpoints of others

Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise that the point of view in a literary text influences how readers interpret and respond to events and characters
Topic: Recognise that the point of view in a literary text influences how readers interpret and respond to events and characters
Elaboration: Comparing texts narrated from a first person and third person point of view, and discussing what information the audience can access and how this influences the audience’s sympathies
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •scaffolded activities to record a personal response to a character or event in a text, and find examples of the point of view that has shaped that response

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise that the point of view in a literary text influences how readers interpret and respond to events and characters
Topic: Recognise that the point of view in a literary text influences how readers interpret and respond to events and characters
Elaboration: Discussing why an author might choose a particular point of view

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Examine the effects of imagery, including simile, metaphor and personification, and sound devices in narratives, poetry and songs
Topic: Examine the effects of imagery, including simile, metaphor and personification, and sound devices in narratives, poetry and songs
Elaboration: Discussing how figurative language including simile and metaphor can make use of a comparison between different things
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •opportunities to listen to the way authors use sound devices in a range of texts

ContentDescription: Examine the effects of imagery, including simile, metaphor and personification, and sound devices in narratives, poetry and songs

Elaboration: Discussing how figurative language including simile and metaphor can make use of a comparison between different things

ContentDescription: Examine the effects of imagery, including simile, metaphor and personification, and sound devices in narratives, poetry and songs
Topic: Examine the effects of imagery, including simile, metaphor and personification, and sound devices in narratives, poetry and songs
Elaboration: Discussing how, by appealing to the imagination, figurative language provides new ways of looking at the world

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts, experimenting with figurative language, storylines, characters and settings from texts students have experienced
Topic: Create and edit literary texts, experimenting with figurative language, storylines, characters and settings from texts students have experienced
Elaboration: Drawing upon fiction elements in a range of model texts; for example, main idea, characterisation, setting (time and place) and devices; for example, figurative language (simile, metaphor, personification), to experiment with new, creative ways of communicating ideas, experiences and stories in literary texts
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •deconstructing and jointly constructing texts with teacher support

ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts, experimenting with figurative language, storylines, characters and settings from texts students have experienced

Elaboration: Drawing upon fiction elements in a range of model texts; for example, main idea, characterisation, setting (time and place) and devices; for example, figurative language (simile, metaphor, personification), to experiment with new, creative ways of communicating ideas, experiences and stories in literary texts

ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts, experimenting with figurative language, storylines, characters and settings from texts students have experienced

Elaboration: Creating a visual map, which may include digital mind maps, of figurative language, storylines, characters and settings in a text that may inspire their own writing

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Describe the ways in which a text reflects the time and place in which it was created

Elaboration: Describing how ideas in texts are conveyed by vocabulary, including idiomatic expressions, and that these can change according to time and place

Topic: Describe the ways in which a text reflects the time and place in which it was created

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver spoken and multimodal presentations that include relevant, elaborated ideas, sequencing ideas and using complex sentences, specialist and technical vocabulary, pitch, tone, pace, volume, and visual and digital features
Topic: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver spoken and multimodal presentations that include relevant, elaborated ideas, sequencing ideas and using complex sentences, specialist and technical vocabulary, pitch, tone, pace, volume, and visual and digital features
Elaboration: Experimenting with features of voice such as tone, volume, pitch and pace in formal presentations and recognising the effects these have on audience understanding

ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver spoken and multimodal presentations that include relevant, elaborated ideas, sequencing ideas and using complex sentences, specialist and technical vocabulary, pitch, tone, pace, volume, and visual and digital features
Topic: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver spoken and multimodal presentations that include relevant, elaborated ideas, sequencing ideas and using complex sentences, specialist and technical vocabulary, pitch, tone, pace, volume, and visual and digital features
Elaboration: Reflecting on how new learning can be incorporated into a presentation

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use phonic, morphemic and vocabulary knowledge to read and spell words that share common letter patterns but have different pronunciations
Topic: Use phonic, morphemic and vocabulary knowledge to read and spell words that share common letter patterns but have different pronunciations
Elaboration: Recognising and writing less familiar words that share common letter patterns but have different pronunciations; for example, “journey”, “your”, “tour” and “sour”
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •opportunities to learn words in context and in real life situations and practise pronunciation

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Build and spell new words from knowledge of known words, base words, prefixes and suffixes, word origins, letter patterns and spelling generalisations
Topic: Build and spell new words from knowledge of known words, base words, prefixes and suffixes, word origins, letter patterns and spelling generalisations
Elaboration: Using knowledge of known words and base words to spell new words; for example, the spelling and meaning connections between “vision”, “television” and “revision”

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Build and spell new words from knowledge of known words, base words, prefixes and suffixes, word origins, letter patterns and spelling generalisations
Topic: Build and spell new words from knowledge of known words, base words, prefixes and suffixes, word origins, letter patterns and spelling generalisations
Elaboration: Applying knowledge of spelling generalisations to spell new words; for example, “suitable”, “likeable” and “collapsible”

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore less common plurals, and understand how a suffix changes the meaning or grammatical form of a word
Topic: Explore less common plurals, and understand how a suffix changes the meaning or grammatical form of a word
Elaboration: Using knowledge of word origins and roots, and related words, to interpret and spell unfamiliar words, and learning about how these roots affect plurals; for example, “cactus” and “cacti”, “louse” and “lice”

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore less common plurals, and understand how a suffix changes the meaning or grammatical form of a word
Topic: Explore less common plurals, and understand how a suffix changes the meaning or grammatical form of a word
Elaboration: Understanding how some suffixes change the grammatical form of words; for example, “-tion” and “-ment” can change verbs into nouns: “protect” to “protection” and “develop” to “development”
